user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of setup_reply_properties:
```c
static void
setup_reply_properties (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  struct MHD_Response *const r = c->rp.response;  /**< a short alias */
  enum replyBodyUse use_rp_body;
  bool use_chunked;

  mhd_assert (NULL != r);

  /* ** Adjust reply properties ** */

  c->keepalive = keepalive_possible (c);
  use_rp_body = is_reply_body_needed (c, c->rp.responseCode);
  c->rp.props.send_reply_body = (use_rp_body > RP_BODY_HEADERS_ONLY);
  c->rp.props.use_reply_body_headers = (use_rp_body >= RP_BODY_HEADERS_ONLY);

#ifdef UPGRADE_SUPPORT
  mhd_assert ( (NULL == r->upgrade_handler) ||
               (RP_BODY_NONE == use_rp_body) );
#endif /* UPGRADE_SUPPORT */

  if (c->rp.props.use_reply_body_headers)
  {
    if ((MHD_SIZE_UNKNOWN == r->total_size) ||
        (0 != (r->flags_auto & MHD_RAF_HAS_TRANS_ENC_CHUNKED)))
    { /* Use chunked reply encoding if possible */

      /* Check whether chunked encoding is supported by the client */
      if (! MHD_IS_HTTP_VER_1_1_COMPAT (c->rq.http_ver))
        use_chunked = false;
      /* Check whether chunked encoding is allowed for the reply */
      else if (0 != (r->flags & (MHD_RF_HTTP_1_0_COMPATIBLE_STRICT
                                 | MHD_RF_HTTP_1_0_SERVER)))
        use_chunked = false;
      else
        /* If chunked encoding is supported and allowed, and response size
         * is unknown, use chunked even for non-Keep-Alive connections.
         * See https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7230#section-3.3.3
         * Also use chunked if it is enforced by application and supported by
         * the client. */
        use_chunked = true;
    }
    else
      use_chunked = false;

    if ( (MHD_SIZE_UNKNOWN == r->total_size) &&
         (! use_chunked) )
    {
      /* End of the stream is indicated by closure */
      c->keepalive = MHD_CONN_MUST_CLOSE;
    }
  }
  else
    use_chunked = false; /* chunked encoding cannot be used without body */

  c->rp.props.chunked = use_chunked;
#ifdef _DEBUG
  c->rp.props.set = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
The rule concerns modification of the function parameter pointer itself (here: parameter 'connection'), not modification of the object it points to. I inspected the function for any assignments or operations that change the parameter pointer or reassign an alias to a different address. Findings:

- The only use of the parameter is to create a const pointer alias: "struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection;". The alias is a const pointer (pointer itself is const), so this does not modify the parameter and prevents later reassignment of the alias.
- A second alias is created: "struct MHD_Response *const r = c->rp.response;". This is also a const pointer and there is no reassignment to it or to the original parameter.
- All subsequent writes are to members of the object pointed to by the parameter (e.g., c->keepalive, c->rp.props.*). Modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is explicitly permitted by the rule.
- There are no occurrences of pointer arithmetic, reassignments to connection/c, or passing the address of the parameter for modification.

Because there are no statements that modify the pointer parameter itself, there are no code fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
